chapter.title: Tuning systems with &saptune;
chapter.para: This chapter presents information about tuning &productname; to work optimally with &sap; applications.
Using &saptune;, you can tune a system for &netweaver;, &hana;/&bo;, and &s4h; applications.

important.para: This chapter describes &saptune; version 3 which does not use &tuned; anymore.

sect1.title: Staging
sect1.para: It is possible, that a new &saptune; package can contain both: binary changes (for example, bug fixes) and new or altered &sapnote;s and &sapsol;s. This can be unfavorable for some customers. Installation of bug fixes or new features might be wanted, but altering the systems configuration at the same time might not.
With staging enabled, &sapnote; and &sapsol; changes shipped with a package update are not active immediately. They are placed in a staging area, which can be reviewed and released later.

important.para: With the current implementation a package update will overwrite the staging if staging is enabled.

sect1.title: Tuning kernel parameters manually using sysctl
sect1.para: In addition to or instead of tuning kernel parameters using &saptune;, you can also use sysctl to make manual adjustments to kernel parameters. However, such changes using sysctl do not persist across reboots by default. To make them persist across reboots, add them to one of the configuration files read by sysctl.

tip.title: sysctl and &saptune;
tip.para: If you plan to configure sysctl parameters for your &sap; system, consider using &saptune; as the central tool for managing such configurations.

sect1.para: For more information about sysctl, see the man pages sysctl(8), sysctl.conf(5), and sysctl.d(5).
